sections.summary: Mankind is warned of their approaching reckoning while they remain distracted and continue to ridicule the mortal nature of messengers. The sources clarify that all previous messengers were mortal men who required food, and those who rejected their warnings were crushed while the faithful were saved.

This range describes the destruction of guilty towns and the subsequent realization of their inhabitants who cried out in regret. Their appeals were of no avail as they were rendered into silent ashes by the divine **decree**.

Allah establishes that the heavens and earth were not created for amusement but to allow truth to crush **falsehood**. It affirms absolute **monotheism (Tawhid)**, stating that the existence of other gods would have resulted in the ruin of the universe [433–434].

The text refutes the claim that the Most Merciful has taken a son, identifying angels as honored servants who act only on His command. Any being claiming **divinity** besides Allah is promised the reward of Hell as a penalty for such transgression.

These verses highlight natural proofs of sovereignty, including the separation of the heavens and earth and the origin of every living thing from **water**. It mentions the placement of mountains as stabilizers and the precise **orbits** of the sun and moon.

No human being is granted immortality, and every soul is destined to taste **death** as a finality. Humanity is tested through both adversity and prosperity, yet disbelievers often respond to these warnings and the proximity of the Hour with **ridicule**.

Allah is established as the sole guardian against the Merciful, and the text describes the gradual reduction of land as a sign of His power. On Resurrection Day, the **scales of justice** will be set up so that no soul suffers injustice, even for the weight of a mustard seed [435–436].

Moses and Aaron are granted the **Criterion (Torah)** as an illumination and a reminder for the righteous who fear their Lord in private. The Quran is identified as a similarly **blessed message** sent down for those who will not deny it.

Abraham challenges his people’s devotion to **idols**, eventually reducing the statues to pieces to prove their helplessness. After his people attempted to burn him, Allah commanded the fire to be **coolness and safety**, delivering him to a blessed land [436–437].
Abraham is gifted with Isaac and Jacob, both of whom were made righteous leaders. The text also notes the deliverance of Lot from a city practicing **abominations**, admitting him into divine mercy.

Noah’s appeal is answered, resulting in the delivery of his family from a great disaster. Allah supported him against a people who rejected His signs, eventually drowning the **evildoers** in their entirety.

David and Solomon are granted **wisdom and knowledge**, with nature itself subjected to their service. This includes the mountains and birds glorifying Allah with David, and the stormy winds and devils serving Solomon's commands [437–438].
Job’s cry for mercy during great harm is answered by his Lord, who lifted his suffering. His family was restored to him as a **mercy** from Allah and a reminder for all future worshipers.

The steadfastness of Ishmael, Enoch, and Ezekiel is recognized, alongside Jonah’s rescue from darkness after his **repentance**. It also recounts Zechariah’s prayer for an heir and the sign of the Virgin Mary, into whom Allah breathed His **Spirit**.

sections.theme: The Unified Community and the End
sections.summary: While humanity was meant to be one community, they splintered into factions that will all return for judgment. The text warns of the release of **Gog and Magog** and the folding of the heaven like a book on the Day the first creation is repeated [438–439].

sections.theme: Inheritance of the Earth and Mercy
sections.summary: It is written in the Psalms that the earth will be inherited by the **righteous servants**. The Messenger is described as a **mercy to mankind**, and the surah concludes with a plea for the Gracious Lord to judge with truth.
